image.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

item.title: Iraq condemns 'reckless' attacks on bases
item.description: Iraq's military condemned actions against its bases and captured a truck with a rocket launcher after at least five US personnel were injured in an attack. This incident occurred amidst rising tension in the Middle East due to the Gaza war and fears of reprisals by Iran and its allies. The military is investigating to bring the perpetrators to justice.

item.title: Bangladesh ex-PM Khaleda Zia freed after arch-rival Sheikh Hasina toppled amid unrest
item.description: Bangladesh's uncompromising ex-prime minister Khaleda Zia has been released from years of house arrest after her bitter enemy Sheikh Hasina was ousted as premier and fled as protesters stormed her palace. She was later released into house arrest on condition she neither took part in politics nor went abroad for medical treatment.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: What is Jamaat-e-Islami? 'Pakistan-backed' political party that brought down Sheikh Hasina govt in Bangladesh
item.description: Amid widespread violent protests, Bangladesh's Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina resigned and fled to India. Army chief General Waker-uz-Zaman announced an interim government and military control to restore order. Jamaat-e-Islami, an influential Islamist party, has faced bans and crackdowns due to its history of violent activities and extremist connections, presenting ongoing challenges for Bangladesh's stability.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Maitree Express between Dhaka and Kolkata remains suspended
Who is Nahid Islam, soft-spoken sociology student leader behind fall of Bangladesh government
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Who was Sheikh Mujibur Rahman? Architect of independent Bangladesh
item.description: Amid political unrest in Bangladesh, Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina resigned and sought refuge in India. This situation mirrors her earlier exile nearly 48 years ago, following the assassination of her father, Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, along with his family. Rahman was Bangladesh's first president, whose death in a military coup led to successive coups and power struggles.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: How Israel's Mossad took down enemy with Belgian chocolates and toothpaste laced with poison
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Caught on camera: Pickup truck slams into pedestrians on NYC sidewalk
item.description: A shocking event took place in Harlem when a pickup truck lost control, mounted the sidewalk, and struck two pedestrians. The incident occurred around 4:50 p.m. at the intersection of St. Nicholas Avenue and West 148th Street. Both victims were hospitalized and are in stable condition, while the driver remained uninjured and on the scene.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Kamala Harris makes history: Secures Democratic nomination as first woman of color on major party ticket
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'Making too many smart people stupid': Joe Rogan's new special on trans, Covid criticised by critics
item.description: Joe Rogan's new Netflix special, "Burn the Boats," faced criticism for mocking transgender people and questioning COVID-19 vaccines. The podcaster defended his controversial views and opposed society's acceptance of trans people in certain spaces. The special drew harsh reactions and ignited debates over his comments on transgender issues and vaccine skepticism.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Elon Musk's X to close San Francisco office, ending Twitter's 20-year presence
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Hurricane Debby’s unexpected find: $1 million in cocaine found on Florida beach amidst hurricane aftermath
item.description: Hurricane Debby, which hit Florida on Monday, resulted in the surprising discovery of 25 packages of cocaine on a Florida Keys beach. A concerned citizen alerted authorities, leading to the confiscation of the $1 million worth of drugs. This follows a similar find in July when Tampa's mayor discovered cocaine during a vacation.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: $950 million fine for funeral home fraud: Is this enough for families whose loved ones were left to rot?
item.description: Jon and Carie Hallford, owners of Colorado funeral home 'Return to Nature,' were ordered to pay $950 million to families deceived by their fraudulent practices. Charged with corpse abuse and theft, they face further legal action. The ruling aims to bring understanding and accountability, as Colorado lawmakers push for stricter funeral home regulations.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Prince William 'spitting mad' at brother Harry, but why?
item.description: Prince William reportedly expressed anger towards Prince Harry for bringing up Princess Diana in recent interviews. Harry mentioned Diana's experiences with media hacking, but William is upset over what he sees as Harry's continuous exploitation of their mother's memory since marrying Meghan. This tension further strains their relationship and impacts Royal Family dynamics.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Virginia man's chilling death threats against Kamala Harris exposed in FBI investigation
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Gunmen kill New Zealand helicopter pilot in Indonesia's Papua, indigenous passengers freed
item.description: In Indonesia's Papua region, gunmen, allegedly from the West Papua Liberation Army, killed New Zealand pilot Glen Malcolm Conning after landing in Mimika district. The helicopter was set ablaze while Indigenous Papuan passengers were released. The attackers retreated into the jungle. The incident has heightened tensions between Indigenous Papuans and Indonesian authorities.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Tropical storm Debby ravages Florida and Georgia: Many dead, cities flooded
item.description: Tropical Storm Debby caused severe damage across the southeastern US, leading to several deaths, mass evacuations, and extensive flooding. Rescue operations are ongoing in Florida and Georgia, with over 500 people saved from flooded homes. Power outages affected more than 300,000 people as authorities urged residents to stay vigilant, with the storm still posing significant threats.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk
